Name: Samuel H. Wright
Address: Hilton, Montana
Birthplace: Bradford, Yorkshire, England

1. INQUIRY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1903
   Where did you get your homestead? Augusta, Idaho
   How far had you been living before that? Yorkshire, England
   For how many people did you provide meals? Three adults
   How far was it to your nearest store? 20 miles to Leducton
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice in winter time
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Almost everything except what we grew on the farm

2. FLours AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lea & Wilson, Leducton Milling Co.
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds each
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3-$5
   How much did you use rye flour? Small quantity
   Whole wheat flour? Small quantity
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 30 miles (last year) 1903-1910
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 6¢ cents
   What other grain products did you use? Oats
   Cornmeal? Wheat
   Whole wheat? Rye
   Other? Wheat
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it?
Almost everything except what was grown on the farm.

2. PLUMS AND PEARS (1911-1912)

- Sold by Mr. Wilson, Sebastopol, Willing Co.
- In each quantity did you buy 100 lbs., 1000 lbs., or more?
- What was the usual price per hundred pounds at Wilson's?
- You mean did you use fresh fruit?
- How much flour did you sell locally?
- How much flour did you sell out-of-state?
- What was the price for a twenty-pound box of walnuts?
- What other edible products did you sell?
- Cornmeal?
- Wheat?
- Did you sell flour in bags for personal use?
- How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...10 pounds.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...5 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Rayner.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...5 oz. or 10 oz. can.

At what price? ...5 cents per oz.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...from cows.

Butter? ...homemade cream.

What was the price of butter? ...20 cents.

Did you make butter? ...yes.

Did you make cheese? ...yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...beef by the quarter.

How did you get fresh meat? ...frozen in the winter, canned in the summer.

How often did you get fresh meat? ...twice a week.

How did you preserve meat? ...salted, smoked, and canned.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...not at that time.

If so, what year was it organized?

Did you use game? ...yes, little.

For how long? ...during the open season.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...good protein.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...fresh.

Kinds? ...white fish, salt fish, and herring.

3. **SUGAR AND SUGARINE**

   In what quantity did you buy sugar recently? [100 pounds]

   What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? [8¢ per lb.]

   Next brand of molasses corn syrup did you use? [Kapora]

   What size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? [1 lb. in Amber, 1 lb. in glass]

   At what prices? [6¢ each]

4. **BUTTER PRODUCTS**

   How did you get supplies of fresh milk in the early years?

   Did you ever have a cow? [Yes]

   What was the ratio of butter to milk? [1:1]

   Did you make butter? [Yes]

   Did you make cheese? [No]

5. **CANDY AND CANDIES**

   What was your main supply in the early years?

   Did you build a candy store? [Yes]

   How did you get your candy? [From the candy store]

   How often did you eat candy? [Daily]

   How did you purchase most of your candy? [At the store]

   Was there a "candy man" in your neighborhood? [Yes]

   Did you ever work at a candy store? [Yes]

   For how long? [During the summer]

   What part did you play in the family diet? [A small part]

   How much money did you spend on candy? [About $5]

   Was the candy fresh, canned, or confectionery? [Fresh]

   How much food, fresh, canned, or confectionery? [About $5]
6. **BUTTER**

   What kind of butter did you buy? Blue Ribbon (or other brand)...
   How much did you buy? 4 lbs...
   How much did you pay? $1.50...

7. **VEGETABLES AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTS**

   What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you got up housekeeping?
   Was there a dollar? Yes...
   If not, where from?...
   What year did you first grow your own supply for the table?...
   Potatoes... Cabbages... Carrots... Onions... Turnips... Beets...

   How did you buy produce? (in bulk or by the box)?...

   What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
   Dried apples, raisins & currants & apricots...

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ... well on our farm ...........................................

How far was this water from your home? ... 20 yards ........................

How was it brought to the house? (Pail, barrel, tank) ... Pail ................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had to keep going deeper to keep supply up, 6-8 years since we left the farm
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well, on our farm.

If so far was this water from your house? ... 25 yards.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank).

Ten traveling water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading.

We had to buy going supplies to keep supply up.

6-8 years since we left the farm.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

There were many products we bought by bulk in the early years, that are sold in packages now.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast Porridge, bacon, egg, white + brown bread
Butter tea or coffee with cream
Dinner Beef or pork, potatoes, carrots or turnips or cabbage
Bread + butter, tea, pudding, etc. or Yorkshire
Supper Bread + butter, greenfruit canned, sometimes meat + fried potatoes

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? ...1923... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Beef + chicken, Plum Pudding, Bread + Butter
Vegetables, etc.
Mrs. Mrs. S. Wright, Mrs. Wright-Senior
37 yr W.B. Russell a neighbor.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had plenty to eat and were always had a good garden which kept us going, our own milk + butter + eggs and beef + pork even during the depression not much money moving during that time.
There were many furnishings we bought by bulk in the early years, that are sold in packages and thus saved.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family or number.

Breakfast: Porridge, bacon eggs, white & brown bread

Dinner: Beef or pork, potatoes, carrots, turnips or cabbage, bread & butter, tea, fruitcake, juice or grapefruit

Supper: Bread & butter, potatoes, canned corned beef, tea

That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In what month?

Vegetables, etc.

Mrs. Mrs. S. Wright - Mrs. Wright Junior

We always had plenty to eat and always had a good garden which helped us grow our own milk & butter & eggs and beef & pork even during the depression.

List any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

There were many products we bought by bulk in the early years, that we sold in packages and this year.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always had plenty to eat and were always had a good garden which kept us going, our own milk & butter, eggs and beef & pork even during the Depression.

Not much money moving during that time.
16. SWAPMEET AND CONTESTS

Please list any contests which you entered. In the contesting and competing, we were very successful in the food we served and gave away.

This was many years ago, when we sold our packages and thus never...

17. Give a typical dinner menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest part of the year. Give the name and list the members of the family at dinner.

Breakfast: Porridge, bacon, eggs, toast, jam, coffee.

Dinner: Beef or pork, potatoes, carrots, turnips, creamed spinach.

Supper: Bread & butter, dessert, milk.

18. Tell us what you did for your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kentucky.

That year, we had our first Christmas dinner in eastern Kentucky.

19. Have you ever returned to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods?

We always had plenty to eat and were always able to get a good garden, which helped us grow our own milk and butter, eggs, and beef and pork, even during the Depression.

During that time, I remember being very poor.
20. Noting any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There are better stores today & more variety in food products.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We left the farm in 1942—but we always have had a garden for canning & summer use since then.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We always found the local stores always satisfactory, we had no cold storage plant available, which we have today for keeping fresh fruits & vegetables frozen also meats of different kinds, we had to can everything in the early days, we sold our grain at the local elevator such as oats, barley and wheat, we could buy good coal from Drumheller also at our local station at $5.00 per ton some difference now, we have tried to answer these questions to the best of our ability. Samuel Wright.
Then did you begin to rely on preserved foods and improved forms of livestock as protein sources?

We bought from a local farm in 1942 - but we always had a garden for growing vegetables.

We always found the local stores disappointing, which we have today for buying fresh fruits and vegetables frozen or canned meats of different kinds, we need to can any thing in the way we sell our grain at the local elevator such as oats, barley, and wheat.

We could buy good coal from the local station at 300 per ton area difference now.

Samuel Wright
